snippet: Three studies published in the past few weeks show that self-reporting of concussions by college football players varies by position.
abstract: Three new studies published in The Journal of Neurotrauma and The Hournal of Law, Medicine & Ethics find that self-reporting of concussions by college football players varies by position; also indicates that efforts by the NCAA and other groups to raise awareness of concussions has been uneven, and that freshmen are more likely than upperclassmen to believe that their coach would think reporting a concussion is the right thing to do.
lead_paragraph: Three studies published in the past few weeks show that self-reporting of concussions by college football players varies by position.

headline.main: College Players Often Don’t Tell of Hits to Head, Studies Find
headline.print_headline: College Players Often Don’t Tell of Hits to Head, Studies Find
